In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

Here's how you can define the `clean_column` function in Julia:

```julia
function clean_column(col::String)
    # Lowercase the column name
    lc_col = lowercase(col)
    
    # Strip leading and trailing whitespace
    stripped_col = strip(lc_col)
    
    # Replace spaces and hyphens with underscores
    cleaned_col = replace(stripped_col, r"\s|-" => "_")
    
    return cleaned_col
end
```

This function takes a `String` as input representing a column name and returns the clean version of the string. It first lowercases the input, then strips any leading or trailing whitespace, and finally replaces spaces and hyphens with underscores.

You can use this function like so:

```julia
julia> clean_column("My Column")
"my_column"

julia> clean_column("MY COLUMN-  WITH SPACES AND HYPHENS")
"my_column_with_spaces_and_hyphens"
```

This function assumes that the input string does not already contain underscores, as it would create an infinite loop when trying to replace characters with themselves. In practice, you might want to add additional checks or handle edge cases depending on the specific requirements of your project.
